title: 105_s361
content: The Act of 1998 may be cited as the "Rhinoceros and Tiger Conservation Act." Congress finds that the populations of all but 1 species of rhinoceros and the tiger have significantly declined and continue to decline. These species are listed as endangered under the Endangered Species Act and on Appendix I of CITES. Resolutions have been adopted urging Parties to CITES to implement legislation to reduce illegal trade in their parts and products. The decline in tiger and rhinoceros populations is primarily due to poaching for traditional medicines. Legal mechanisms are insufficient to control trade in their parts and products. Legislation is needed to prohibit the importation and exportation of products containing rhinoceros or tiger parts, and to educate the public on conservation efforts and alternatives for traditional medicine products. The Rhinoceros and Tiger Conservation Act of 1994 aims to prohibit the sale, importation, and exportation of products containing substances derived from rhinoceros or tiger species intended for human consumption or application. The Rhinoceros and Tiger Conservation Act of 1994 prohibits the sale, importation, and exportation of products containing substances derived from rhinoceros or tiger species for human use. Section 4 of the Act is amended to define 'person' as an individual, corporation, partnership, trust, association, or government entity. The Rhinoceros and Tiger Conservation Act of 1994 prohibits the sale, importation, and exportation of products containing substances derived from rhinoceros or tiger species for human use. Section 4 of the Act is amended to define 'person' as an individual, corporation, partnership, trust, association, or government entity, including any other entity subject to the jurisdiction of the United States. SEC. 7 of the Rhinoceros and Tiger Conservation Act prohibits the sale, importation, or exportation of products labeled or advertised as rhinoceros or tiger products. The Rhinoceros and Tiger Conservation Act prohibits the sale, import, or export of products containing substances from rhinoceros or tiger species. Violators may face criminal penalties of fines and imprisonment, as well as civil penalties of up to $12,000 per violation. The Rhinoceros and Tiger Conservation Act imposes civil penalties of up to $12,000 for each violation. Penalties are assessed and collected similar to the Endangered Species Act of 1973. Products in violation are subject to seizure and forfeiture. Regulations will be issued after consultation with relevant authorities. The Rhinoceros and Tiger Conservation Act imposes civil penalties of up to $12,000 for violations, enforced by the Secretary, Treasury Secretary, and Coast Guard. Penalty amounts collected will be used in accordance with the Lacey Act Amendments of 1981. SEC. 8. EDUCATIONAL OUTREACH PROGRAM. The Secretary will develop an educational outreach program in the United States for the conservation of rhinoceros and tiger species. Guidelines for the program will be published, and information will be disseminated on laws protecting these species, traditional medicines containing their parts, and the status of rhinoceros and tiger species. The Rhinoceros and Tiger Conservation Act of 1994 is amended to authorize appropriations for the years 1996 through 2002. This amendment was passed by the Senate on October 8, 1998. The amendment to the Rhinoceros and Tiger Conservation Act of 1994 prohibits the sale, importation, and exportation of products containing substances derived from rhinoceros or tiger species for human consumption or application.
